newsitem.title: USA: Argentina orange output seen falling - U.S. attache.
newsitem.headline: Argentina orange output seen falling - U.S. attache.

text.p: Argentina's orange production is forecast to fall to 670,000 tonnes, down five pct from last year, as trees enter a rest phase following a big harvest last year, a U.S. agricultural attache said in a report made public on Thursday.

The report, prepared by the U.S. Embassy in Buenos Aires, said total citrus exports were likely to fall eight percent this year, mostly due to the devaluation of the European currency versus the U.S. dollar. All Argentine citrus exports are priced in U.S. dollars.

Orange production in 1997 is forecast at 670,000 tonnes, down five percent from last year, the report said. Total fresh orange exports in 1997 are forecast to drop by seven percent to 85,000 tonnes, reflecting a smaller supply, the lack of increasing new markets in Southeast Aisa and more phytosanitary barriers by European countries, the report said.
Last year, Argentina exported 91,000 tonnes of fresh oranges, mostly to the Netherlands, Russia and United Kingdom.

Argentina's production of concentrated orange juice (65 degree brix) in 1997 was projected to be flat at 10,000 tonnes. Even though more fresh fruit was destined for processing, the same volume of juice is expected given that the drought in Entre Rios affected the early varieties of oranges, making them practically juiceless, the report said.
Exports of orange juice are forecast at 1,900 tonnes, down from the previous season, due to low international prices, and great competition with imported juices.
Argentina's imports of orange juice reached 8,589 tonnes in 1996, up 134 percent from 1995.
Attache reports are not official USDA figures.
